title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997". Congress finds that private security officers in the United States are growing rapidly, function as an adjunct to public law enforcement, provide entry-level job opportunities, and protect individuals and property. Private security officers offer entry-level job opportunities for individuals affected by unemployment, protecting various properties and operations such as banks, hospitals, airports, and schools. Private security officers provide protection to a wide range of operations including banks, hospitals, chemical companies, airports, and residential properties. Sworn law enforcement officers serve the public in public areas, with private security officers supporting them by offering prevention and reporting services. The growth of private shopping malls has increased the demand for security services. Private security officers supplement sworn law enforcement officers in providing services to the public. With the rise of private shopping malls, people are more likely to interact with private security personnel than with sworn police officers. The growth of private shopping malls has led to a decrease in public shopping streets, resulting in more contact with private security personnel than sworn law enforcement officers. This trend has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, with the goal of making more officers available to combat serious crimes. The trend towards growth in private security services has accelerated as the number of public law enforcement officers has decreased. This growth aims to provide more officers to combat serious crimes, as the public struggles to differentiate between sworn officers and private security personnel. The American public demands the employment of both. Private security personnel are needed to combat serious crimes, but the public has difficulty distinguishing them from sworn law enforcement officers. The American public demands the use of qualified private security personnel as a supplement, not a replacement for sworn officers. Private security officers should undergo thorough screening, especially since many carry weapons. SEC. 3. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Background checks for private security officers require submission of fingerprints or other identification methods to the Attorney General for a background check. Employers can seek authorization from employees for this process, and the Attorney General will search the National Crime Information Index. The Attorney General conducts background checks for private security officers by searching fingerprint records in the National Crime Information Index and the FBI database within 30 days of receiving them from the requesting association. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling records. The Attorney General conducts background checks for private security officers by searching fingerprint records in the National Crime Information Index and the FBI database within 30 days of receiving them from the requesting association. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling records, and associations must submit employee fingerprints promptly for identification and processing. An association designated under this section must promptly submit employee fingerprints to the Attorney General for identification and processing, transferring criminal history records to the employer within one business day. Additionally, the association must provide copies of requests made on behalf of employers to licensing authorities or regulatory agencies in the respective states. The Attorney General must provide criminal history records to employers within one business day. An association designated under this section must also provide copies of requests to licensing authorities and regulatory agencies. The Attorney General may establish regulations for security and confidentiality. The Attorney General must provide criminal history records to employers promptly. The association designated under this section must also provide copies of requests to licensing authorities and regulatory agencies. The Attorney General may establish regulations for security, confidentiality, accuracy, use, and dissemination of information, as well as audits, recordkeeping, and fees for cost recovery. Additionally, a report on the number of inquiries made by employers under this section must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary two years after the enactment of this bill. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Subsection (d) of section 534 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include an association of employers of private security officers designated by the Attorney General for conducting background checks on employees.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Anyone who misuses information obtained under section 3 for purposes other than assessing an individual's suitability for private security officer employment may face a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Using information from section 3 for purposes other than assessing private security officer suitability can result in a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY.

Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions are protected from liability. In this Act, the term "Attorney General" includes any designated person or entity, such as the FBI. The term "employee" includes job applicants. The term "employer" refers to individuals or entities providing private security services and licensed or certified by one or more states. Private security officer is an individual providing security services as an independent contractor, licensed or certified by one or more states. The term "fingerprint" includes any approved method of positive identification. The term "private security officer" refers to an individual who provides security services for compensation, whether armed or unarmed, in uniform or plain clothes. This does not include sworn police officers. The term "fingerprint" encompasses any approved method of positive identification. Private security officers provide security services, whether armed or unarmed, in uniform or plain clothes. This excludes sworn police officers, licensed professionals, and employees primarily involved in internal audit or credit functions. Private security officers in the State may include attorneys, accountants, and other licensed professionals, employees involved in internal audit or credit functions, individuals on active duty in the military service, and employees of electronic security. Employees exempt from private security officer licensing requirements may include individuals on active duty in the military service, employees of electronic security system companies, employees primarily involved in the secure movement of prisoners, and employees of armored vehicle companies. The term "security services" includes observation or reporting of intrusion, larceny, vandalism, fire, or trespass, as well as deterring theft or misappropriation of goods, money, or other valuables. The term "security services" involves observing and reporting intrusion, theft, vandalism, and unlawful activities, as well as protecting individuals and property from harm or misappropriation. It also includes controlling access to premises. The term "security services" includes protecting individuals and property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order at public activities, and providing canine services for detection of unlawful substances. The term "security services" encompass protecting individuals and property, controlling access, maintaining order at public activities, and providing canine services for detecting unlawful substances. The term "State" refers to various states and territories within the United States. SEC. 8. USER FEES. The Attorney General may collect a user fee for requesting an individual's criminal history information. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act will be effective on July 1, 1999.
